items.raw_directive:
1461: :::
1462: :::{prf:remark} Maximal cemetery distance (design choice)
1463: :label: rem-maximal-cemetery-distance-design-choice
1464: This convention selects a maximal, state‑independent distance to the cemetery law so that absorption events represent the largest possible jump in distributional metrics. It simplifies comparisons (no ad‑hoc offsets) and keeps $W_p(\nu,\delta_{\dagger})$ constant across all living $\nu$.

items.label: rem-cloning-scope-companion-convention
items.title: Cloning Scope and Companion Convention
items.raw_directive:
4378: This unified definition handles both alive and dead walkers. For a **dead walker** $i \in \mathcal{D}_t$, its potential $V_{\text{fit},i} = 0$. Its cloning companion $c_{\text{clone}}(i)$ is drawn from the alive set $\mathcal{A}_t$, making its potential $V_{\text{fit},c_{\text{clone}}(i)} > 0$. The score simplifies to $S_i = V_{\text{fit},c_{\text{clone}}(i)} / \varepsilon$. Since the **Global Constraint** $\varepsilon \cdot p_{\max} < \eta^{(\alpha+\beta)}$ is satisfied, the minimum possible score for a dead walker is guaranteed to be greater than the maximum possible threshold: $S_{i, \min} > (\eta^{\alpha+\beta})/\varepsilon > p_{\max}$. Because $T_{\text{clone}}$ is always sampled from $[0, p_{\max}]$, the condition $S_i > T_{\text{clone}}$ is always met. This results in a "Clone" action with probability 1, ensuring the revival mechanism remains an emergent and guaranteed property of the framework.
4379: :::
4380: :::{admonition} Randomness discipline for cloning
4381: :class: note
4382: - For each walker $i$, independently sample the cloning companion index $c_{\text{clone}}(i)\sim \mathbb C_i(\mathcal S)$ (with replacement) using an independent uniform $U_i^{\mathrm{comp}}$.

items.raw_directive:
5170: :label: subsec-measurability-markov-kernel
5171: :::{prf:proposition} The Swarm Update defines a Markov kernel
5172: :label: prop-psi-markov-kernel
5173: Let $(\Sigma_N,\mathcal{B}(\Sigma_N))$ be the measurable state space. Assume each stage of the update—cloning, perturbation, and status update—is defined by a measurable map with respect to its inputs and driven by a measurable noise kernel on a Polish probability space. Then the full Swarm Update Operator $\Psi$ is a Markov kernel on $\Sigma_N$; i.e., for each $\mathcal{S}\in\Sigma_N$, $\Psi(\mathcal{S},\cdot)$ is a probability measure on $\Sigma_N$, and for each measurable $A\in\mathcal{B}(\Sigma_N)$, the map $\mathcal{S}\mapsto \Psi(\mathcal{S},A)$ is measurable.

5199: By definitions in Sections 11.3 and 17.2.4.1, each coefficient is obtained from the stagewise Lipschitz/Hölder functions and bounded parameters via finite sums, products, maxima, and composition with continuous operations (including the map $x\mapsto x^{\alpha}$ for $\alpha\in(0,1]$). Under assumptions (i)–(iii), the inputs to these algebraic operations are bounded and continuous on $\mathcal{K}_R$ by the aggregator axioms and the properties of the patched $\sigma'$ (see [](#lem-sigma-reg-derivative-bounds)). Continuity is preserved under sums, products, and composition; boundedness follows from continuity on compact (or closed, bounded) sets. Hence all listed coefficients are bounded on $\mathcal{K}_R$ and jointly continuous in $(\mathcal{S}_1,\mathcal{S}_2)$.
5200: **Q.E.D.**
